Kinetic study of α-pinene allylic oxidation over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst Jaime-Andrés Becerra Lina-María González ⁎ Aída-Luz Villa Environmental Catalysis Research Group, Chemical Engineering Department, Engineering Faculty, Universidad de Antioquia, Calle 70 No. 52-21, Medellín, Colombia Environmental Catalysis Research Group Chemical Engineering Department Engineering Faculty Universidad de Antioquia Calle 70 No. 52-21 Medellín Colombia ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The kinetic of α-pinene oxidation over an iron hexadecachlorinated phthalocyanine immobilized on modified silica (FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2) with t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant is proposed. Reaction rates were calculated by the initial reaction rate method from the data obtained in a batch reactor, and compared with kinetic expressions proposed from mechanisms based on Langmuir Hinshelwood Hougen Watson (LHHW) and power-rate law models. The kinetic parameters were estimated from the experimental data by optimization using the Genetic Algorithm. A kinetic expression based on LHHW model with the adsorption of α-pinene, TBHP and the main reaction products (verbenone, α-pinene epoxide and verbenol) on the surface of the catalyst predicted the experimental data with good accuracy (R2 =0.986). The apparent activation energy of α-pinene allylic oxidation over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2/TBHP was 40.08kJ/mol. α-Pinene conversion of 83.7% was obtained after 23h with a selectivity to verbenone of 23%. Under the reaction conditions leaching of the active species was not observed; however, the effect of radicals in the bulk liquid phase was demonstrated, confirming that the reaction involves a combination of both heterogeneous and homogeneous pathways. The catalyst can be used at least in seven cycles without loss of α-pinene conversion nor verbenone selectivity. Keywords Allylic oxidation α-Pinene Verbenone Perchlorinated iron phthalocyanine Kinetic study 1 Introduction α-Pinene is a constituent of the turpentine oil obtained from pine plants, which can be converted into more valuable compounds, such as epoxides, alcohols, aldehydes and ketones [1–3]. The α-pinene allylic oxidation leads to the production of α,β-unsaturated compounds verbenol and verbenone (Fig. 1 ), raw materials in the production of flavors, insecticides, therapeutic drugs and food industry [3–9]. Although verbenone is a constituent of strawberry, raspberry, dill, vervain (20.5wt.% [10]), rosmarinus (24.9wt.% [11]) and spearmint flavor mixtures, the synthetic route from α-pinene oxidation to verbenone is of interest. However, during the oxidation of α-pinene two main competitive reactions are present: a) the epoxidation of the double bond to obtain α-pinene epoxide, and b) the allylic oxidation to produce verbenol and verbenone. The predominance of the reactions depends on the catalyst and the stability of the radicals formed during the oxidation [12]. The development of selective α-pinene oxidation using nontoxic solvents, efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts has become a challenging goal in the chemical industry for productivity improvement [13]. Verbenone has been obtained using homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts with moderate yields (Table 1 ) [14,15]; however, the requirement of expensive and toxic solvents [16–19], difficulty in catalyst recovery and product purification [20], inert atmosphere or large amount of catalyst and time, limit the application in some of those systems. Furthermore, in some cases reports do not include catalytic stability [21]. Hexadecachlorinated iron phthalocyanine immobilized on commercial silica FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 (Fig. 2 ), is an active catalyst for the synthesis of allylic ketones under mild reaction conditions (313K, 24h, acetone), with yields to verbenone above 22% using TBHP without not apparent activity loses in three reaction cycles [22]. Metallophthalocyanines (MPc) are structurally similar to metal porphyrins complexes, but more stable to degradation, and widely used as catalysts in several organic reactions, for example in the cyclohexene and cyclohexane oxidation [23–25]. In spite of the numerous reports about the heterogeneous catalytic allylic oxidation of α-pinene, there are few kinetic studies for this reaction. The proposed mechanism over Ti-MCM-41/H2O2 (which gave a 15% α-pinene conversion at 5h, 343K, acetonitrile) includes competitive adsorption of H2O2, α-pinene, acetonitrile and H2O from the H2O2 on the catalyst surface [26] and the surface chemical reaction as controlling step; using the stationary state approximation for the intermediates, the authors found that the reaction rate was first order respect to the concentrations of α-pinene, H2O2 and catalyst, and cero order respect to H2O. However, the formation of oxidation products was not clearly detailed [26]. In other study, a proposed mechanism for α-pinene liquid-phase oxidation by O2 over Pd/C catalyst (343–393K and 0.5–6bar O2 pressure) involves two consecutive steps: (i) α-pinene oxidation by O2 to verbenyl hydroperoxide (VHP) intermediate and α-pinene epoxide and (ii) selective reduction of VHP to verbenol by H2 over the catalyst [27]. The mechanism was proposed as a set of radical chain steps. The authors suggested for the step (i) a kinetic equation of first order regarding to the O2 pressure and half order respect to VHP concentration [27]. Until now, there are no reports about the kinetic of the α-pinene allylic oxidation to verbenone considering both the radicalary mechanism and the heterogeneous catalytic process. In this paper a kinetic study of α-pinene allylic oxidation was performed with the catalytic system FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2/TBHP, using several kinetic expressions based on LHHW reaction mechanism; furthermore, the role of the heterogeneous catalyst and radicals was studied. The kinetic parameters were estimated by optimization using the Genetic Algorithm in Matlab®. In addition, the heterogeneity and stability of FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst was evaluated using leaching and reusing tests. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents All commercial reagents were used without any further purification: (1R)-(+)-α-pinene 98%, tert-butyl hydroperoxide solution (70% aqueous), tetrachlorophthalic anhydride 96%, (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane 99%, fumed powder SiO2, 2,4-di-tert-butylphenol 99% and triphenyl phosphine≥98.5% from Sigma–Aldrich. Acetone ACS reagent≥99.5%, n-decane anhydrous ≥99%, urea ACS reagent and FeCl2·4H2O from Merck. Ammonium heptamolibdate tetrahydrate from J.T. Baker. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The phthalocyanine complex FePcCl16 was synthesized using a well-grounded mixture of urea (11.7g), tetrachlorophthalic anhydride (16g), FeCl2·4H2O (2.8g) and ammonium heptamolibdate tetrahydrate (0.1g) [28]. Before the complex immobilization, the support was modified with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) following a reported procedure [29] and named as NH2-SiO2. The final material was called FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 (detailed procedure in the Supplementary data, section 1. Catalyst preparation). 2.3 Catalyst characterization Metal content of catalyst was determined by atomic absorption in a Model S4 spectrometer from Thermo Electron Corp. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra were carried out in a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 9 spectrometer (200–800nm).N2 adsorption/desorption data were collected in an ASAP 2010 equipment. Thermogravimetric studies were carried out in a Q500 TGA V20.8 (TA Instruments) in oxidant atmosphere using a synthetic air flow of 20mL/min from 25 to 800°C (heating rate: 10°C/min). Raman spectra were collected in a Horiba Jobin Yvon Labram HR spectrometer using a 633nm He–Ne laser. IR spectra was recorded in a Nicolet Avatar 330 FTIR with dispersive cell and 3% diluted sample in KBr. In leaching tests, liquid phase samples were analyzed in a UV–vis spectrophotometer Thermo Spectronic Helios α (200–800nm). 2.4 Allylic oxidation reactions Oxidation reactions were carried out in a vial flask of 2mL heated in an oil bath. In a general procedure the FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 (0–0.25% mol) was added to 1.5mL of α-pinene (0–0.22M) in acetone; then the commercial TBHP (0–0.4M) was added and the reaction mixture stirred at constant temperature (283–323K). The catalyst was removed by filtration and the filtrate analyzed by gas chromatography using a GC Agilent 7890A equipped with flame ionization and MS Agilent 5975C detectors and a HP5 column (ID 0.20mm×length 50m×film 0.5μm), in decane as internal standard; the remaining TBHP was analyzed by iodometric titration. The VHP concentration was determined by the difference between the verbenol concentration before and after filtrate (0.2mL) treatment with triphenyl phosphine (PPh3) 0.19M in ethyl acetate. In the mass transfer limitations evaluation, the reaction was carried out (at the standards conditions: 1.5mL α-pinene/acetone 0.125M, 0.25% mol catalyst, 1.3mmol of 70% TBHP, 313K, 0.5h) at different stirring rates (100–1400rpm) and catalyst particle sizes (107–715μm). The reaction rates were determined by the initial reaction rate method (α-pinene conversion<12% at 0.5h). The presence of free radicals in the reaction was confirmed by adding 2,4-di tert-butyl phenol (0.19mmol) at the beginning of the reaction and maintaining constant the standard conditions [30]. The catalyst recovered by filtration was washed with acetone, dried at 358K for 5h and characterized by Raman spectroscopy, the catalysts was reused (1.5mL α-pinene/acetone 0.131M, 1.3mmol of 70% TBHP, 313K, 1000rpm, 23h) and its lost between reuses was lower than 5wt.%. In leaching tests, the catalyst was removed after 5min of reaction, the filtrate was let at 313K and 1000rpm analyzing samples up to 23h; UV–vis analysis was performed in some liquid samples to determine any leaching of FePcCl16 complex. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The surface area of the iron phthalocyanine immobilized FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 (137m2/g) material was lower that the surface area of the white amorphous commercial silica SiO2 (211m2/g), probably owing to the incorporation of the FePcCl16 complex in the modified silica support NH2-SiO2 (0.38mmol NH2/g). FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 materials (62.62μmol Fe/g) showed a green color; this color arises from ligand π–π* transition of CN bonds associated with monomeric species immobilized on the support, Fig. 3 (UV-vis bands between 400 and 500nm or between 660 and 680nm) [29,31–33]. The UV–vis band near to 630nm confirms the presence of μ-oxo dimeric species [29,34]. The region between 600 and 800nm is referred as the Q band correspond to the π–π* transition from the HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) to the LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of the Pc−2 ring, the broad band in the 300–400nm region consists of more than one component, and is referred to as the Soret region or B band with deeper π–π* transitions [35]. The three-bands in the 200–300nm region, which are referred to as N, L, and C bands in order of increasing energy, are together with the B bands, sensitive to the central metal. It is suggested that Metal to Ligand Charge Transfer (MLCT) and Ligand to Metal Charge Transfer (LMCT) transitions are involved in this spectral region [36]. Fig. S1 shows the infrared and Raman spectra of FePcCl16 complex. The band at 1660cm−1 in the infrared analysis, Fig. S1a, is assigned to the CC stretching vibration in pyrrole and the bands at 1394cm−1 and 1336cm−1 are attributed to CC stretching in isoindole [37,38]. The band at around 1500cm−1 is assigned to the CH bending in aryl groups [38]. The bands at 1190cm−1 and 1019cm−1 belong to CN stretching vibration and in pyrrole, respectively [38]. The band at 923cm−1 is associated to M-N vibrations [32]. The presence of a strong band between 700 and 800cm−1 is attributed to CCl vibrations [39]. In the Raman analysis, Fig. S1b, under excitation of the laser at 633nm, that is closer to the resonance with the main Q absorption band of phthalocyanine, typical vibrational bands were observed. The bands between 650 and 726cm−1 can be associated both with the CCl stretch (550–790cm−1) in the Pc periphery [40] and with the Pc ring “breathing” at around 681–686cm−1 [41–44]. The medium bands at around 780–787cm−1 are associated to CN aza stretching [45]. The weak bands at around 866–867cm−1 are referred with both the coupling of isoindole deformation and with the aza stretching CH bend [41–44]. The strong bands at around 1199–1205cm−1 are typically associated to CH bend, vibrational frequencies in the range of 1300–1600cm−1 derived from isoindole ring stretching and the aza group stretching are selectively intensified [41–44,46]. Medium bands between 1299 and 1322cm−1 correspond to CC pyrrole and benzene stretching, weak and medium bands at around 1335–1457cm−1 are referred to isoindole stretching; and the strong bands at around 1501–1525cm−1 correspond to coupling of pyrrole and aza stretching [41–44]. 3.2 FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst activity The catalytic activity of FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2, the non-immobilized complex FePcCl16 and without catalyst were compared; the effect of adding the free radical inhibitor 2,4-di tert-butyl phenol also was evaluated (Table 2 ). Supported complex onto modified silica increases both selectivity to verbenone and α-pinene conversion up to 26% and 61%, respectively in 3h; the intermediate VHP was also detected. With the presence of 2,4-di tert-butyl phenol the formation of free radicals in the oxidation of α-pinene with or without catalyst is inhibited and the intermediate VHP yield decreased. In consequence, the free radicals are produced by the TBHP even in the absence of catalyst. Using the iron salt FeCl2 as homogeneous catalyst and TBHP as oxidant, α-pinene and TBHP conversion were 65% and 55.9% respectively at 23h, α-terpineol with 46.3% selectivity was the major product; verbenol, verbenone and α-pinene epoxide were not detected. 3.3 Evaluation of external and internal mass transfer limitations External mass transfer limitations were evaluated varying the stirring rate between 100 and 1400rpm (Fig. S2). The highest initial reaction rates were obtained between 750 and 1100rpm, with a maximum at 1000rpm. The effect of the internal diffusion on the reaction rate was evaluated by changing the average particle size (107–715μm) at 1000rpm stirring rate (Table 3 ). Weisz–Prater parameter CWP, was used as a criterion to detect intra particle mass transfer limitations for α-pinene (AP) [47], detailed description in the Supplementary information (section 3. Evaluation of external and internal mass transfer limitations). The pore diameter of catalyst was determined by complete BET analysis, and its average value was 250Å (Fig. S3). The internal mass transfer limitations can be considered absent if CWP ≤3β, where β is the maximum decrease in concentration gradient in pores as function of the reaction order [47]. The β values estimated for second, first and zero order reaction corresponds to 0.1, 0.2 and 2, respectively [47]. As a criterion for non-internal diffusional limitations in the reaction, it was assumed a second order reaction which requires a value of CWP ≤0.3 [47]. Table 3 shows that a value of CWP ≤0.3 is obtained using an average particle size of 107μm. Thus, all further experiments in this kinetic study were carried out over catalyst with a particle size≤107μm and at a stirring rate between 750 and 1100rpm. 3.4 FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst stability and recycling The catalyst stability was evaluated with reuses and leaching tests, α-pinene (AP) and TBHP (B) conversion, and selectivity to main products are shown in Fig. 4 . The oxidizing agent was almost consumed and α-pinene conversion was 83.7% at 23h. The main products were verbenone (VE), verbenol (V) and α-pinene epoxide (PO) with 24%, 5% and 10% of selectivity respectively; and other terpenes in small quantities were also detected. Fig. 5 shows that α-pinene conversion and the main products selectivity at 23h remains almost constant in the 7th reaction cycle. Fresh FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 and catalyst after the 7th reaction cycle were characterized by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 6 ) as a suitable characterization technique, since SiO2 has important bands belong 600cm−1 [48] and the FePcCl16 bands can be easily identified in contrast with IR analysis [49]. The identified Raman bands in the fresh catalyst (Fig. S1b) were also observed in the catalyst after the 7th cycle, Fig. 6, which shows that the catalyst does not lose its chemical structure. Fig. 7 shows the results of leaching test analysis. The C1 plot corresponds to the reaction with catalyst and TBHP in which α-pinene conversion of 83.7% was obtained at 23h. The C2 test was conducted similar to C1, but the catalyst was removed by filtration after 5min of reaction, α-pinene conversion increased from 11.1% at 5min up to 45.2% in 23h after removing the catalyst; this increment was not associated with Fe leaching but it was owing to the reactivity of free radicals formed during the interaction of TBHP and α-pinene with the catalyst. In C3 test the effect of 2,4-di-tert-butyl phenol as inhibitor of those free radicals was studied; the reaction was carried out as C1, but after catalyst removal at 5min of reaction, the free radical inhibitor was added to the reaction mixture; in this case α-pinene conversion only increased from 10.4% at 5min to 16.1% at 23h, which indicates an inhibition of the radicals formed by the addition of the 2,4-di-tert-butyl phenol. When the inhibitor of free radicals was added at the beginning of the reaction, test C4, and the catalyst was removed after 5min, the α-pinene conversion remained constant in 9.7% after 23h of reaction. The C5 test was carried out without TBHP, α-pinene conversion of 2.4% at 23h with α-pinene epoxide and allylic products formation was observed due to the presence of low amounts of ambient O2 inside of the reactor. Thus, from comparison of results of C2 with C3 and C4 tests it can be established that free radicals formed for the interaction of TBHP and α-pinene with the catalyst were also responsible for the substrate oxidation. When free radicals were inhibited, α-pinene conversion did not change significantly after removing the catalyst, so it is concluded that there was not leaching of the active species into the reaction medium under the reaction conditions used. UV–vis data absorption of the liquid reaction mixture after catalyst removal (Fig. S6 in the Supplementary information) supports the leaching tests results. The analysis was conducted for reaction samples at different reaction times: t=0 (without catalyst), t=5min (C2 reaction condition from Fig. 7), t=1h, and t=23h (C1 reaction condition from Fig. 7). The bands of FePcCl16, Fig. S6b, does not appear in the reaction mixture after removing the catalyst, indicating that there was a total catalyst separation and non-leaching of FePcCl16. The growth of UV–vis bands with time at 350 and 366nm (Fig. S6a) are associated with the products formation. Bands between 250 and 380nm correspond to verbenol and verbenone (Fig. S7). 3.5 Determination of the kinetic rate law and reaction mechanisms The variation of the initial α-pinene reaction rate with the initial concentration of α-pinene, TBHP and Fe, and temperature was experimentally determined, Fig. 8 . Initial α-pinene reaction rate vs. TBHP and α-pinene concentration seems to follow a LHHW tendency (Fig. 8 a and Fig. 8 b), in which the adsorption of both reactants at high concentrations is in nearest-neighbors sites [50]. The linear increment of initial α-pinene reaction rate with iron concentration (Fig. 8 c) may be related with heterogeneous reactions in which the adsorptions are not the limiting steps in the reaction [51]. The apparent activation energy calculated with the Arrhenius equation from Fig. 8 d data was 40.08kJ/mol, with a linear coefficient determination R2 of 90%, an appropriated value for reaction-limiting step in heterogeneous processes [51]. Several kinetic expressions were proposed with the assumption of a reaction-limiting step and using the steady-state approximation for intermediates, Table 4 . The kinetic parameters were estimated by optimization of the objective function ( O F ) given by Eq. (1) using the genetic algorithm in Matlab®. (1) O F = ∑ i = 1 N ( r ' A P 0 − r ' c a l , A P 0 ) 2 Where: r ' A P 0 and r ' c a l , A P 0 are the experimental and calculated α-pinene initial reaction rate, respectively. The models were compared using statistical parameters [52,53]: variance s2 , square root mean deviation Rmsd , coefficient of determination R 2 , adjusted coefficient of determination R a d j 2 , and 95% confidence intervals (IC). Table 4 shows the kinetics expressions proposed for the α-pinene initial reaction rate based on pseudo-homogeneous (PH) and LHHW models, and presents LHHW-based models for the α-pinene reaction rate adjustment up to 23h of reaction. A good fit of the experimental data was obtained with the reaction rate that includes the adsorption of α-pinene, TBHP and the main reaction products on the phthalocyanine surface from LHHW-based model. 3.5.1 Mechanism approximation – LHHW From the data analysis in Fig. 8 is possible to propose one of the reaction mechanisms reported by Murzin [50], who presented different kinetic equations depending on the limiting-step and the type of mechanisms based on LHHW. (2) AP+S↔AP*S (3) B+S↔B*S (4) AP*S+B*S→P*S+S (limiting step), (5) P*S↔P+S In this mechanism α-pinene (AP) is adsorbed over the surface of the catalyst (S), Eq. (2), then TBHP (B) is adsorbed, Eq. (3), generating also free radical initiators [54,55]. At a later stage, the adsorbed species interact resulting in different oxidation products (P*S), Eq. (4). Finally products are desorbed from the catalyst surface, Eq. (5). Considering the surface reaction, Eq. (4), as the limiting step, the reaction rate of α-pinene may be expressed by Eq. (6). Applying the equilibrium conditions for the adsorption and desorption steps, and considering the total concentration of active catalytic sites as C t o t a l = C S + C A P . S + C B . S , α-pinene reaction rate may be expressed by Eq. (7): (6) − r ' A P = k ( 4 ) C A P . S C B . S (7) − r ' A P = k 1 C A P C B ( 1 + K 1 C A P + K 2 C B + K 3 C P ) 2 3.5.2 Deepening in the reaction mechanism Additional tests were carried out looking for more information about the reaction mechanism, Fig. 9 . The α-pinene conversion increased with time, but in most of the cases this increment was insignificant from 6 to 23h. When the reaction was carried out with the heterogeneous catalyst FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 and TBHP, α-pinene conversion was 83.7% at 23h, (R-1). With TBHP and without catalyst, α-pinene conversion was 20.5% at 23h, (R-2). Over the catalyst and without TBHP, α-pinene conversion was 2.4% in 23h, (R-3). Without catalyst neither TBHP, α-pinene conversion was 2.4% at 23h, (R-4). In presence of 2,4-di-tert-butyl phenol as inhibitor of free radicals and using catalyst and TBHP, α-pinene conversion was 8.6% at 23h, (R-5). With TBHP and with the modified support NH2-SiO2, α-pinene conversion was 9.1% at 23h, (R-6). Without TBHP and with the non-supported complex FePcCl16, α-pinene conversion was 7.9% at 23h, (R-7). Although the kinetic expression given in Table 4 gives a good fit of the experimental reaction rate data, the results in Fig. 9 indicate that there are not only heterogeneous effects on the reaction; notwithstanding, the highest substrate consumption is under heterogeneous conditions. Also the substrate oxidation is due to the radicals generated in the bulk phase, because the homogeneous interaction of the substrate with TBHP and with the oxygen present in the reaction media, Fig. 9. 3.5.2.1 Homogeneous pathway According to Neuenschwander et al. [56], under non-catalytic conditions, radicals can be generated from ROOH molecules (TBHP in this case) via thermal chain-initiation with slow homolytic dissociation of the OO bond, Eq. (8); it has also been proposed that the initiation can be carried out due to the fast bimolecular reaction between ROOH and substrate (RH) or some ketones [57,58], Eq. (9). In those reactions, OH-radicals from hydroperoxide abstracts an H-atom, forming H2O and a C-centered radical, which is stabilized by delocalization [58]. (8) ROOH→RO* + *OH (9) ROOH+ RH→RO* +H2O+ R * (10) RO* + RH→ROH+ R * (11) R * +O2 → ROO* (12) ROO* + RH→ ROOH+ R * The RO* radicals in the presence of substrate RH produce R * radicals Eq. (10), which can interact with molecules of oxygen for producing ROO*species Eq. (11), and some intermediates like verbenyl hydroperoxide (ROOH) which was identified and quantified in the catalytic activity tests (Table 2), responsible for the formation of allylic products verbenol (ROH) and verbenone (R =O), and α-pinene epoxide (EO) [56], Eq. (12) to Eq. (16): (13) ROO* + ROOH+ RH→ x ROOH+ x R * +(1 −x)ROH+(1 −x)RO* + R =O+H2O (14) RO* + ROOH→ ROH+ ROO* (15) RO* +O2 → R =O+HOO* (16) ROO* + RH→ RO* + EO The cross reaction of ROO* radicals can produce RO* in Eq. (17), or the possible chain-termination reaction in Eq. (18) [56]: (17) 2ROO* →2RO* +O2 (18) 2ROO* → ROH+ R =O+O2 When α-pinene oxidation reaction was carried out without TBHP (with or without catalyst), low α-pinene conversion (2.4%) at 23h was obtained because of the presence of O2 in the reaction media (curve R-3 and R-4 in Fig. 9), α-pinene epoxide was detected with a selectivity of 28.3%, and allylic products verbenone and verbenol with selectivities of 19.6% and 14.3%, respectively. The oxidation carried out without catalyst, but in presence of TBHP increased α-pinene conversion up to 20.5% at 23h, (curve R-2 in Fig. 9), verbenone, verbenol and α-pinene epoxide were detected at those conditions with selectivities of 4.2%, 2% and 6%, respectively. 3.5.2.2 Heterogeneous pathway The participation of O2 produced during the reaction was evidenced experimentally. TBHP conversion of 86.2% was achieved over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 and without α-pinene at 6h. The O2 formation was verified qualitatively when the reactor pressure increased, Eq. (19). In the liquid phase tert-butanol (ROH) and di-tert-butyl peroxide (ROOR) were obtained at 6h with selectivities of 87.7% and 10.6% respectively, Eq. (20). The TBHP decomposition into tert-butyl alcohol and O2 was reported by Lin Qi et al. using birnes site-type manganese oxides catalysts [59]. In addition, the formation of di-tert-butyl peroxide and tert-butanol was reported in the TBHP decomposition over Beta-zeolite catalyst [60]. When the reaction was carried out in presence of acetone, the consumption of TBHP was 91.2%, with similar selectivity to tert-butanol and di-tert-butyl peroxide; and no reaction products from the solvent were detected, indicating that the solvent is stable under the tested reaction conditions. The evidence of O2 formation in this case was lower than the reaction without solvent due to O2 solubility in acetone and the use of lower amount of catalyst. When the terpene was added to the reaction medium, it was not detected an increase of the reactor pressure probably due to the rapidly consumption O2 in some steps of the reaction. The reaction mechanism associated with the TBHP decomposition in the catalyst surface can be simplified in several steps. Basically, TBHP in the presence of macrocycles compounds such as phthalocyanines, porphyrins or when reacted with biomolecules like cytochrome P450 and cytochrome c (containing Fe as a central metal in its structure) forms a peroxo-bond with the central metal iron [61], Eq. (21). The peroxo-complex may have two types of chemical breaks in the peroxo-bond [62], in the homolytic break LFeIV =O active species and free radicals of the form RO* are produced, Eq. (22); in the heterolytic breaking active species L+*FeIV =O and tert-butyl alcohol (ROH) are formed [61], Eq. (23). The two phthalocyanine active species react with TBHP to form free radicals ROO* type, Eq. (27) and Eq. (28). (19) 2 ROOH→2 ROH+O2(g) (20) ROOH+ROH→ROOR+H2O Several reported heterogeneous catalysts increase the formation of radicals in olefin oxidation by homolytic and heterolytic activation of hydroperoxides [54]. The homolytic decomposition can be described through the Haber–Weiss mechanism that usually involves the presence of transition metal ions [63,64]. The heterolytic decomposition may include dehydration and/or disproportionation reactions [65]. If FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 is used for α-pinene oxidation with TBHP, the combined effect of homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions, increases α-pinene conversion up to 83.7% in 23h, (curve R-1 in Fig. 9) with respect to the homogeneous conditions (curve R-2 in Fig. 9). The mechanism of reaction under those circumstances should include the free radicals formation pathway due to the interaction of TBHP with the catalyst, that was confirmed in the reactions performed with 2,4-di-tert-butyl phenol as inhibitor of free radicals (section 3.2 and 3.4). In the heterogeneous pathway, ROOH species (TBHP in this case) may react with active metal sites to produce alkyl hydroperoxo complexes, Eq. (21): (21) ROOH+LFeIII →LFeIII − (−)OOR+H(+) This alkyl hydroperoxo complex (LFeIII-OOR) can undergo both homolytic and/or heterolytic cleavage of the OO bond to form LFeIV =O or LFeV =O adapting L+*FeIV =O state according to Eq. (22) and Eq. (23), respectively [65]. The mechanism of the OO bond cleavage depends on the nature of the hydroperoxide and ligand environment L [65]. Heterolytic cleavage often is associated to biological and bio-inspired systems like porphyrin or phthalocyanine macrocycles which stabilize the high oxidation state via participation of the ligand in the charge delocalization [66]. The [LFeV =O ↔ L+*FeIV =O] species are known to be strong epoxidizing agents, which can be responsible for α-pinene epoxide (EO) formation, Eq. (24). (22) LFeIII − (−)OOR→LFeIV =O+RO* (23) LFeIII − (−)OOR→[LFeV =O↔L+*FeIV =O]+ROH (24) [LFeV =O↔L+*FeIV =O]+ RH→ EO +LFeIII The formation of LFeIV =O and RO* via homolytic cleavage of OO bond favors the allylic oxidation, and can be responsible for the verbenol (ROH) formation according to Eq. (25) and Eq. (26). (25) LFeIV =O+ RH→ R * +LFeIV −OH (26) R * +LFeIV −OH→ ROH+LFeIII (27) LFeIV =O+ROOH→LFeIII +ROO* (28) [LFeV =O↔L+*FeIV =O]+ROOH→LFeIII +ROO* The formation of verbenone ketone (R =O) is related with several interactions of radicals, chains termination steps or from ROH oxidation, Eq. (29) to Eq. (32) [8,67–69]. For this system when verbenol was subjected to reaction condition with FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst and TBHP, verbenol was converted 100% to verbenone with 86.2% selectivity at 23h, Eq. (32). Free radicals generated during the interaction with the catalyst with TBHP have some interactions and radical terminations steps, Eq. (33) to Eq. (34), to produce more t-butanol, (ROH) and di-tert-butyl peroxide (ROOR) [55,61,70]. (29) 2ROO* → R =O+ ROH+O2 (30) RO* + ROO* → ROOH+ R =O (31) ROO* + R * → R =O+ ROH (32) ROH+ROOH→ R =O+ROH+H2O (33) RO* +ROOH→ROO* +ROH (34) 2RO* →ROOR (35) 2ROOH→ROO* +RO* +H2O Moreover, monomeric and μ-oxodimeric species of FePcCl16 immobilized on NH2-SiO2 have been related with the activity of FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst [29]. Those iron binuclear species can participate in the formation of radicals by homolytic and heterolytic cleavage of OO bonds and could participate in the formation of verbenol, verbenone and α-pinene epoxide, as monomeric species [66], Eq. (36) to Eq. (37): (36) LFeIII −O−LFeIII −OOR→LFeIII −O−LFeIV =O+RO* (37) LFeIII −O−LFeIII −OOR→[LFeIII −O−LFeV =O↔L+*FeIV −O−LFeIV =O]+ROH The addition of an inhibitor of radical chain processes immediately stopped the reaction over the catalyst and in the bulk phase; α-pinene conversion of 8.6% was reached at 23h (curve R-5 in Fig. 9). This could be explained by suppression of the growth of radical chains in the homogeneous oxidation process or by adsorption of the inhibitor on the active metal sites, which may lead to the catalyst poisoning [65], but in both cases was due to the interaction of the inhibitor with radicals responsible for the chain propagation in the bulk phase or over the catalyst surface. A pathway of TBHP free-radical initiation in the α-pinene oxidation (Fig. 10 ) is proposed and based on the following statements: - The presence of both catalyst and TBHP is necessary to accomplish α-pinene oxidation. - Immobilization of the FePcCl16 complex enhanced its catalytic activity. When FePcCl16 was immobilized on amino-modified fumed silica (FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2), verbenone formation increased four times, Table 2. - Monomeric and μ-oxodimeric species of FePcCl16 immobilized on NH2-SiO2 have been related with the activity of the FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 [29]. - The radical pathway of the allylic oxidation of α-pinene with the catalytic system FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2/TBHP was confirmed by the formation of VHP [29], as well as the activity inhibition detected in the presence of 2,4-di tert-butyl phenol, entries 2 and 5 of Table 2. - α-Pinene epoxide formation was appreciable over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 (16% yield), this epoxide was obtained from an electrophilic attack of the L+*FeIV =O on the double bond of the olefin [55]. - The reaction is also carried out without catalyst, in homogeneous conditions due to the thermal activation of TBHP; α-pinene conversion of 20.5% was reached at 23h, curve R-2 in Fig. 9. - The addition of the free radicals inhibitor (2,4-di tert-butyl phenol) reduces the activity of the system; α-pinene conversion of 8.6% was reached at 23h, curve R-5 in Fig. 9. - When the reaction was carried out without TBHP (with or without catalyst), α-pinene conversion of 2.4% at 23h was obtained because of the presence of O2 in the reaction media, Fig. 9. 4 Conclusions In summary, FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 is a stable and active catalyst for the allylic oxidation of α-pinene with TBHP under mild reaction conditions; α-pinene conversion of 83.7% was obtained after 23h with a selectivity to verbenone of 23%. Reusing tests and Raman analysis of the catalyst after reaction confirmed that the catalyst can be used at least 7th times without significant loss of its catalytic activity or stability; several tests allowed concluding that there was not leaching of FePcCl16 from the supported catalyst. UV–vis characterization of the FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 confirms the immobilization of monomeric and μ-oxo dimeric species on the support, which can be the active species in the allylic oxidation reaction of α-pinene with THBP. Several kinetic expressions were proposed based on pseudo-homogeneous and LHHW mechanisms. Although the kinetic model based on the LHHW mechanism, which included the adsorption of α-pinene, TBHP and the main reaction products (verbenone, α-pinene epoxide and verbenol) on the surface of the phthalocyanine, describes the experimental data, the reaction kinetic of α-pinene oxidation over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2/TBHP was not entirely heterogeneous. Under non-catalytic conditions radicals were generated from TBHP molecules via thermal chain-initiation, and in catalytic conditions due to the TBHP interaction with the monomeric and μ-oxo dimeric species of the iron phthalocyanine, which undergo in a homogeneous pathway. However, the substrate consumption was the highest under heterogeneous conditions. Additional reaction tests, let us to determine the importance of the radicalary pathway in the catalytic system studied and the production of oxygen from the oxidant decomposition and its participation in the reactions. coredata.dc:description: The kinetic of α-pinene oxidation over an iron hexadecachlorinated phthalocyanine immobilized on modified silica (FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2) with t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant is proposed. Reaction rates were calculated by the initial reaction rate method from the data obtained in a batch reactor, and compared with kinetic expressions proposed from mechanisms based on Langmuir Hinshelwood Hougen Watson (LHHW) and power-rate law models. The kinetic parameters were estimated from the experimental data by optimization using the Genetic Algorithm. A kinetic expression based on LHHW model with the adsorption of α-pinene, TBHP and the main reaction products (verbenone, α-pinene epoxide and verbenol) on the surface of the catalyst predicted the experimental data with good accuracy (R2 =0.986). The apparent activation energy of α-pinene allylic oxidation over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2/TBHP was 40.08kJ/mol. α-Pinene conversion of 83.7% was obtained after 23h with a selectivity to verbenone of 23%. Under the reaction conditions leaching of the active species was not observed; however, the effect of radicals in the bulk liquid phase was demonstrated, confirming that the reaction involves a combination of both heterogeneous and homogeneous pathways. The catalyst can be used at least in seven cycles without loss of α-pinene conversion nor verbenone selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetic study of α-pinene allylic oxidation over FePcCl16-NH2-SiO2 catalyst
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
